description: Hefty, powerful, and the latest in self-loading pistol technology, this deep blue-finished handgun is the current issue sidearm of United States Army officers and non-infantry troops, chambered in the 45-Automatic cartridge and feeding from detachable 7-round box magazines.  This piece might well have seen your contemporaries through the great war; you just hope it’ll also stand up to your current predicament.

variants.description: A hefty pistol with diamond-checkered grip panels, a thumb safety, and a blued finish, this is the United States Army’s .45-calibre handgun for officers and non-infantry troops, model 1911.  Judging by the firearm's worn grips and slide serrations, rough fitment, and u-notch rear sight, it’s likely either a veteran of the Great War’s trenches, a shooter’s venerable friend, or both.

Finished with handsomely blued metal, checkered plastic grips, and a serrated trigger, this iterative design of the Colt Government model is the latest, formalised pattern of the United States Army's standard .45-calibre handgun.  Either a military contract Colt or a civilian example, regardless of its nature, the large pistol fits comfortably in the hand with a reassuring weightiness.

description: A big, stout, 6-chambered marshal revolver with a brush-blue finish and army acceptance markings edging its frame and grips, this pistol was created by the Colt firm to supplement shortages of the American Expeditionary Force’s standard automatic handgun during the Great War.  Persisting in inventory, police, and civil use well after 1919, it is chambered in the .45-caliber automatic cartridge.

variants.description: A weighty, revolving pistol with a swing-out cylinder, crescent front sight, and brush-blued finish, this double-action handgun is chambered for the .45 Automatic Colt Cartridge and possesses a lanyard ring.  Manufactured by Colt, under request from the US government, to free up 1911 automatics for dispatch to the war in Europe, this particular gun possesses a machined shoulder in each of the chambers to retain the rimless .45 Auto cartridge without the need for moon clips.

description: A submachine gun chambered in .45 ACP and accepting Thompson magazines.

variants.description: An American-made submachine gun developed during the very end of World War I, too late to see action.  Infamous during the 1920s for its use by gangsters, and used during World War II before being mostly replaced with less-expensive alternatives.
